Award.AwardTitle: WIN2017 at the University of California, Irvine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant, under the direction of Professor Mu-Chun Chen of the University of California, Irvine, provides partial support for WIN2017: The 26th International Workshop on Weak Interactions and Neutrinos.

Since their inception in 1973, the WIN workshops have become the major biannual international meetings in the field of neutrino physics. Neutrinos are subatomic particles which are extremely light and interact only weakly. As such, they play critical roles both in traditional elementary particle physics as well as astrophysics and early-universe cosmology. Although originally focused on neutrino physics and weak interactions, the scope of these biannual workshops has become much broader in recent years and now includes flavor physics (a poorly understood area within traditional particle physics) and astro-particle physics. WIN 2017 will take place at an especially important time, when major neutrino experiments worldwide are ramping up their operations. These experiments will open up the neutrino sector for detailed study, and are widely anticipated to yield profound new results concerning the fundamental building blocks of the natural world and the forces they experience. Thus, this grant advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical law. WIN 2017 will be the first WIN meeting held in the United States since 2003, and will be the last opportunity for an American WIN meeting until 2021. The requested funds will contribute to the training of junior researchers by allowing them to participate, gain valuable experience, present their research results, and boost their visibility within the larger scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 26th International Workshop on Weak Interactions and Neutrinos (WIN2017) took place at the University of California, Irvine, from June 19 - 26, 2017. The series of WIN Workshops have been organized regularly for the past 40 years at many venues in Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America, and the United States. The goal is to offer the physics community a significant opportunity to assess the status of major topics within the field and initiate collaborative effort to address current challenges. The Workshops attract leading experimentalists and theorists, from all over the world, allowing them to exchange ideas and to develop new strategies.

Intellecture Merit: WIN2017 was attended by 201 participants, including leading experts in the field as well as graduate students and postdoc scholars. The program was structured to allow ample time for formal and informal discussions in the four working groups: (i) Neutrino Physics, (ii) Electroweak Interactions, (iii) Flavor and Precision Physics, (iv) Astro-particle Physics and Cosmology. The recent advancements in field were presented in 30 plenary talks and in 129 talks during the parallel working group sessions. 

Broader Impacts: The proposal supported 24 graduate students and postdocs to attend WIN2017 and present their research results. This provided good training to the junior physicists and excellent opportunities for them to exchange ideas and get feedbacks from senior physicists in the field. Significant efforts were made to encourage the participation of excellent female and under-represented minority physicists.
